section.title: Gerunds and infinitives
section.sectiontitle: The verbs enjoy, avoid, imagine, consider, finish, miss, practise, involve, carry on and suggest are followed by a gerund.
section.text1a: Does the job involve working in the evenings?
section.sectiontitle2: The verbs want, seem, offer, decide, hope, afford, agree, arrange, promise, refuse and manage are followed by an infinitive.
section.text3a: He offered to give me a lift into town.
section.text4a: I promised to collect her from the station.

section.title: Gerunds and infinitives
section.sectiontitle: The verbs persuade, convince, encourage, allow and advise are followed by an object and an infinitive verb.
section.text1a: I encouraged her to work as hard as she could.
section.text2a: We persuaded the police officer to help us.
section.sectiontitle2: The verbs remember, regret, try, stop and go on are followed by a gerund or an infinitive depending on the meaning.
section.text3: I was talking to Sam and then I stopped.
section.text4: I stopped what I was doing and started talking to Sam.
